author: big_tech_sux
content: btw testing out our EOF implementation in vyper and due to the RJUMPI / CALLF problems mentioned in dec or january, vyper contract codesize actually gets worse by 3-5% when compiling for EOF target

author: axic3354
content: that's interesting, solidity actually got smaller, but maybe they were using all features

author: axic3354
content: do you have some example code so we can investigate?

author: big_tech_sux
content: well it's going to be pretty much any code

author: axic3354
content: i mean an example input + output

author: big_tech_sux
content: for instance instead of being able to JUMPI to a shared revert block, we have to branch and CALLF a shared revert block

author: axic3354
content: oh that's why we have JUMPF ðŸ™‚

author: big_tech_sux
content: ok maybe i am still misunderstanding the new jumpf semantics

author: axic3354
content: no, but it removes the stack balancing restrictions of callf for revert blocks

author: big_tech_sux
content: we can't conditionally call a subroutine without branching

author: axic3354
content: those opcodes were considered but not implemented

author: big_tech_sux
content: ok so anyway like i said, due to stack validation restrictions, code targeting eof actually gets bigger, not smaller

author: big_tech_sux
content: and it turns out not to be pathological, i am testing with various real life sample contracts

author: axic3354
content: yes that's expected, depends on the cases/compilers/design

author: axic3354
content: the first motivation is validation and runtime oriented, code size is secondary
